title: Paper: Midwifery FQE July 2024
description: Final Qualifying Examination for Diploma in Community Health Nursing (Midwifery) - July 2024

questions.question: During the pre-historic age midwifery was practiced by:
questions.explanation: Historically, before the formalization of midwifery education, childbirth was attended by 'Traditional Birth Attendants' (TBAs) or community women who gained skills through experience rather than formal training.
questions.hint: Think about traditional birth attendants.

questions.question: You are teaching anatomy and physiology to newly admitted nursing students. The features that are true about the android pelvis that you would share with them include:

options.text: Rounded brim, narrow fore pelvis, Ischial spines blunt
Fore pelvis wide, sciatic notch wide, sub-pubic angle more than 90°
Sciatic notch rounded, brim rounded, ischial spines
Rounded brim, side walls are straight, fore pelvis generous

questions.explanation: The Android pelvis is typically heart-shaped with a narrow fore pelvis. While 'rounded brim' is usually Gynaecoid, in the context of elimination, Option A contains 'Narrow fore pelvis' which is the distinguishing feature of the Android (male-type) pelvis compared to the generous fore pelvis of the Gynaecoid.
questions.hint: Android means 'male-like' - think funnel shaped.

questions.question: You are recording your findings on the partograph. An indicator of progress in established labor would be:

options.text: Cervical dilatation to the Right of the Alert Line
Cervical dilatation to the Right of the Action Line
Foetal descend of 5/5 at 8 cm dilatation
Two uterine contractions every 10 min lasting 10 sec

questions.explanation: Note: The provided options actually describe delayed or poor progress. Crossing to the Right of the Alert Line indicates delay. 5/5 descent at 8cm indicates obstruction. 2 contractions in 10 mins is uterine inertia. If forced to choose an 'indicator' mentioned in the context of monitoring (often asking for danger signs), crossing the Alert line is the key warning signal.
questions.hint: On a partograph, graphing to the right indicates delay.

questions.question: According to the schedule for Targeted Postnatal Care, the second visit typically occurs within:
questions.explanation: The standard PNC schedule is: 1st visit within 48 hours, 2nd visit within 1-2 weeks, 3rd visit at 6 weeks, and 4th visit at 6 months.
questions.hint: It happens a week or two after birth.

questions.question: You are reviewing a pregnant woman and indicate she is para 1+1. The universal meaning of parity is:

options.text: The number of times a woman has been pregnant
A woman who has never given birth at all
The number of pregnancies a woman has delivered at term/viability
A woman who has delivered more than five (5) times

questions.explanation: Parity refers to the number of pregnancies that have reached viability (regardless of whether the child was born alive or stillborn). Option A defines Gravidity.
questions.hint: It relates to viable births.

questions.question: In midwifery, the pelvic joints that are particularly relevant include:

options.text: One symphysis pubis, two sacroiliac joints, two sacrococcygeal joint
One symphysis pubis, two sacroiliac joints, one sacrococcygeal joint
One symphysis pubis, one sacroiliac joint, one sacral joint
Sacral joint, one sacroiliac joint, one symphysis pubis

questions.explanation: The pelvis has 4 joints: The Symphysis Pubis (anteriorly), two Sacroiliac joints (laterally), and the Sacrococcygeal joint (posteriorly).
questions.hint: Count the joints: Front, Back, and two Sides.

questions.question: The diameters of the pelvic brim are important in obstetrics. The diameters are:

options.text: Anteroposterior diameter, oblique diameter, transverse diameter
Longitudinal diameter, transverse diameter, oblique diameter
Oblique diameter, longitudinal diameter, anteroposterior diameter

questions.explanation: The pelvic brim (inlet) has three main diameters: The AP (Conjugates), The Oblique (Left and Right), and the Transverse diameter.
questions.hint: Front-to-back, side-to-side, and diagonal.

questions.question: During fetal development, the organs formed from the ectoderm layer include:

options.text: Bones, muscles, the heart and blood vessels

questions.explanation: Ectoderm forms the 'outer' structures like Epidermis (skin), Hair, Nails, and the Nervous system (CNS/PNS). Mesoderm forms bones/muscles. Endoderm forms gut lining.
questions.hint: Ecto means outer - think skin and brain.

questions.question: The membranous space on the fetal skull that separates the frontal bones from the two parietal bones is called the:
questions.explanation: The Coronal suture runs from ear to ear, separating the Frontal bone from the Parietal bones. The Sagittal suture separates the two parietal bones.
questions.hint: Like a crown (Corona) sitting on the head.

questions.question: During pregnancy, physiological changes in the alimentary system include:

options.text: Increased Oesophageal peristalsis, accompanied by gastric reflux
Gastric reflux is more prevalent in early pregnancy

questions.explanation: Progesterone causes smooth muscle relaxation, leading to decreased peristalsis/motility (constipation) and relaxation of the cardiac sphincter (heartburn/reflux).
questions.hint: Things slow down to absorb more nutrients.

questions.question: Which of the following defines normal labor?

options.text: The foetus, placenta, and membranes are expelled through the birth canal
The Foetus is expelled through birth canal at full dilatation of cervix
A series of passive movements of the foetus through the birth canal
A foetus at term, in vertex presentation, is spontaneously expelled within 18 hours without complications

questions.explanation: Normal Labour (Eutocia) is defined by: Term gestation, Vertex presentation, Spontaneous onset/delivery, Time limit (<18-24h), and healthy outcome for mother and baby.
questions.hint: It must be spontaneous, term, and uncomplicated.

questions.question: In false labor, contractions are characterized as:

options.text: Painful, regular, increase in frequency and strength
Painful, regular, are accompanied by backache

questions.explanation: False labor (Braxton Hicks) contractions are Irregular in frequency, duration, and intensity. They do not result in cervical dilation. True labor is regular and progressive.
questions.hint: False labor is inconsistent.

questions.question: Moulding is identified by detecting changes in:
questions.explanation: Moulding is the alteration in the shape of the fetal head caused by the overriding/overlapping of the cranial bones at the sutures to reduce diameters.
questions.hint: Bones sliding over each other.

questions.question: During labour, uterine muscles contract and retain the shortening. This is:
questions.explanation: Retraction is the property of uterine muscle fibers to remain shortened after a contraction, progressively reducing the uterine cavity size.
questions.hint: It keeps the muscle short.

questions.question: The sinciput, face and chin sweep perineum as nape of neck pivots lower border of symphysis pubis. This mechanism is:
questions.explanation: This describes birth by Extension. The occiput pivots under the symphysis pubis, allowing the face to emerge.
questions.hint: The head looks up and out.

questions.question: During daily examination, genitalia of a newborn is checked for:

options.text: Labia Majora that does not cover the labia minora

questions.explanation: Pseudo-menstruation is a normal physiological finding in female neonates due to maternal hormone withdrawal. The question implies checking for expected or normal variations versus abnormalities.
questions.hint: A normal hormonal response in female babies.

questions.question: Newborn holds object firmly enough to be momentarily lifted off the cot. This is referred to as:
questions.explanation: The Palmar Grasp reflex is strong enough in healthy newborns to support their partial weight.
questions.hint: Holding on tight.

questions.question: Probable signs for 2nd stage of labour include:

options.text: Expulsive uterine contractions, no cervix felt
Trickle of blood, expulsive uterine contractions
Gaping of the vulva, no cervix felt
No cervix felt, gaping of the anus

questions.explanation: Probable signs include expulsive contractions, trickle of blood (show), and gaping of anus/vulva. 'No cervix felt' is a POSITIVE/Definite sign, not just probable.
questions.hint: Look for the option without 'No cervix felt' as that is a definite sign.

questions.question: A woman who is at 32 weeks gestation has had ruptured membranes for 26 hours. As a midwife, you would assess the woman for:
questions.explanation: Prolonged Rupture of Membranes (PROM > 18-24 hrs) carries a high risk of Chorioamnionitis (infection). Fever is a key sign.
questions.hint: Prolonged rupture leads to infection.

questions.question: The most common causative organism of ophthalmia neonatorum is:
questions.explanation: Chlamydia trachomatis is the most common infectious cause worldwide. Neisseria causes the most severe form.
questions.hint: The most prevalent STI causes the most common eye infection.

questions.question: During the first few days of life the type of jaundice the neonates get as a normal process is called:
questions.explanation: Jaundice appearing after 24 hours due to immature liver function is physiological and normal.
questions.hint: It is a normal physiological process.

questions.question: The first step you would take to prevent hypothermia in a neonate is to keep baby warm by:

options.text: Skin to skin contact with mother
Keep clothed baby under heat source

questions.explanation: Skin-to-skin contact (Kangaroo care) is the standard 'Warm Chain' intervention immediately after drying.
questions.hint: The mother's body is the best heat source.

questions.question: Preterm baby refers to a baby born:

options.text: Between 28 weeks to 34 weeks of pregnancy

questions.explanation: WHO definition of preterm birth is any birth before 37 completed weeks of gestation.
questions.hint: 37 is the cutoff.

questions.question: Predisposing factors to asphyxia neonatorum include:
questions.explanation: Cord Prolapse (no oxygen), APH (reduced blood flow), and Prematurity (immature lungs) are direct causes of asphyxia. Immunity is irrelevant to asphyxia.
questions.hint: Think about things that cut off oxygen supply.

questions.question: Epidural anaesthesia given to relief labor pains is contra-indicated in women with:

options.text: Multiple pregnancy, coagulation disorders, breech presentation

questions.explanation: Absolute contraindications: Hypovolemia (causes hypotension), Coagulopathy (bleeding risk), and Local Infection (meningitis risk).
questions.hint: Bleeding, Shock, and Infection.

questions.question: A nonpharmacologic strategy of pain relief during labour, in which the woman’s awareness of the external environment is reduced is known as:
questions.explanation: Hypnosis creates a trance-like state reducing external awareness.
questions.hint: It involves a trance.

questions.question: Risks associated with teenage pregnancy during the antenatal period include:

options.text: Post-partum haemorrhage, intra-uterine fetal death, malnutrition

questions.explanation: Teenagers are at high risk for STIs, nutritional Anemia, and Pre-eclampsia.
questions.hint: Infections and blood pressure.

questions.question: Hyperemesis gravidarum is associated with the following conditions:

options.text: Infective hepatitis, hydatid form mole, pyelonephritis
Multiple pregnancy, first pregnancies, hydatid form mole
Hydatid form mole, infective hepatitis, malaria

questions.explanation: Conditions with high HCG levels (Molar pregnancy, Twins) cause severe vomiting.
questions.hint: High hormones = More vomiting.

questions.question: The following criteria is used to initiate ART in women who are HIV positive and pregnant:

options.text: On the same day HIV diagnosis is made
At a gestational period of 28 weeks

questions.explanation: Option B+ (Test and Treat) requires immediate initiation for all pregnant women.
questions.hint: Immediate action.

questions.question: A baby born to a diabetic mother should be observed closely for:
questions.explanation: Infants of Diabetic Mothers get Hypoglycemia (low sugar), RDS, and Jaundice.
questions.hint: Low sugar, lung problems, yellow skin.

questions.question: An institution that ensures that children are placed in suitable homes in line with the best interest of the child is:
questions.explanation: Adoption agencies manage placement and vetting of homes.
questions.hint: They handle adoptions.

questions.question: The structures involved in third degree perineal tears are:

options.text: Injury to perineum involving perineal muscles but not involving the anal sphincter
Injury to the perineum involving the anal sphincter complex
Injury to the anal sphincter including the rectal mucosa

questions.explanation: 3rd degree tear involves the anal sphincter. 4th degree involves rectal mucosa.
questions.hint: Muscles plus the sphincter ring.

questions.question: In frank breech:

options.text: Thighs are flexed but the legs are extended to the abdomen
Legs are flexed but thighs are extended
Both thighs and legs are extended
Both thighs and legs are extended and feet tucked behind the buttocks

questions.explanation: Frank breech means hips flexed, knees extended (feet near head).
questions.hint: Pike position.

questions.question: The manoeuvre used in delivering breech with extended legs is:
questions.explanation: Pinard's maneuver flexes the extended knee to deliver the foot.
questions.hint: P for Pop the knee.

questions.question: The presenting diameter in face presentation is:
questions.explanation: Sub-mento bregmatic (9.5 cm) presents in a fully extended face presentation.
questions.hint: Below chin to top of head.

questions.question: The characteristic of third degree inversion of the uterus is:

options.text: The inverted fundus extends through the cervix but remains within the vagina
The inverted fundus extends to, but not through the cervix
The inverted fundus extends outside the vagina
Both the vagina and uterus are inverted

questions.explanation: Third degree inversion is complete prolapse where the fundus is outside the introitus.
questions.hint: It is visible outside.

questions.question: The best position to place a patient during correction of inversion of the uterus is:
questions.explanation: Trendelenburg (head down) allows gravity to assist in replacing the uterus.
questions.hint: Use gravity to pull it back in.

questions.question: The outcome of labour in short internal rotation in occipito posterior position is:
questions.explanation: Short rotation leads to Direct Occipito Posterior (DOP) position, where the baby is born Face to Pubis.
questions.hint: The face looks up.

questions.question: The characteristics of monozygotic twins include that they:

options.text: Have two amnions, two chorions, fertilized by one spermatozoa
Develop from one ovum, same sex, two placentae
Have one amnion, different sexes, one placenta
Are of same sex, develop from one ovum, have one placenta

questions.explanation: Monozygotic twins are genetically identical (same sex) and typically share a placenta (monochorionic).
questions.hint: One egg, one placenta, same sex.

questions.question: Mrs. R is rhesus negative. Under what circumstance would she be eligible for RH (D) immune globulin (RhIG)?

options.text: If her fetus was found to be Rhesus negative
If her fetus heartbeat was tachycardic
If her fetus blood type was found to be Rhesus positive

questions.explanation: RhIG is only needed if the mother is Rh- and the baby is Rh+ (risk of isoimmunization).
questions.hint: The mismatch matters.

questions.question: Which of the following are objectives of Focused Antenatal Care (FANC)? (Select 4)

options.text: Early detection and treatment of complications

questions.explanation: The four main pillars of FANC are: Disease prevention/health promotion, Early detection/treatment, Birth preparedness, and Complication readiness.
questions.hint: Focus on the medical and planning goals.

questions.question: Select three (3) common breast complications that may occur during puerperium.
questions.explanation: Common complications are Engorgement, Cracked Nipples (trauma), and Mastitis (infection).
questions.hint: Think of issues related to breastfeeding start.

questions.question: What are two physiological effects of severe pain during labor? (Select 2)

options.text: Maternal hyperventilation leading to respiratory alkalosis

questions.explanation: Pain triggers a stress response (catecholamines) and hyperventilation, both of which can reduce oxygen delivery to the fetus.
questions.hint: Pain causes stress.

questions.question: Match the anatomical relations of the female reproductive system (uterus) with their location:
questions.explanation: The bladder is in front, rectum behind, and uterus in the middle.
questions.hint: Think about what is in front and behind the womb.

questions.question: Arrange these passive movements of normal labor in correct order after descent:
questions.explanation: The head flexes, then rotates internally, then extends to be born.
questions.hint: Tuck chin, turn head, look up.

questions.question: Identify the key components of Active Management of the Third Stage of Labor (AMTSL). (Select 3)
questions.explanation: AMTSL consists of: 1. Oxytocin w/in 1 min, 2. CCT, 3. Uterine Massage.
questions.hint: Drug, Pull, Rub.

questions.question: Select the correct causes and signs of Oligohydramnios. (Select all that apply)

options.text: Sign: Smaller fundal height than dates

questions.explanation: Oligohydramnios (low fluid) is caused by renal failure (no urine) or leakage. Signs include small uterus and molding of uterus around fetus.
questions.hint: Low fluid means the baby is cramped and 'dry'.

questions.question: Regarding the management of a Small for Gestational Age (SGA) baby in the first 48 hours, which interventions are indicated? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Initiate early and frequent feeding to prevent hypoglycemia

questions.explanation: SGA babies are prone to Hypothermia (large surface area) and Hypoglycemia (low reserves). Management focuses on warmth, frequent feeding, glucose monitoring, and infection control.
questions.hint: Focus on warmth and sugar levels.
